poem:
**Wonky Eggs and Green Spaces**

Home from the Cadbury clatter,  
mother's mismatched treasures spill—  
chocolate eggs, imperfectly sweet,  
like Birmingham's green quilt, patchy yet real.  
Amongst whispers of 'shit-hole', we laugh,  
finding grace in misshaped moments,  
a crack in the shell, a glimpse of light—  
every year, closer to happiness.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Joe Lycett: ‘Every year I get more of an understanding of what I need to be happy’ My mum worked at the Cadbury factory. One perk of the job was an onsite shop where you could buy the chocolate that hadn’t come out quite right, and occasionally she’d arrive home with a heavenly bag of wonky Creme Eggs. Brummies have adopted the sense that we live in a shit-hole, but in terms of green space,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
